Ilattitas Itios Kihrrabit.
EVERY MAN.
RING me some balm, oh
soothing Folly!
My Lady Care hath
scourged me deep
With all the whips of
Melancholy.
Bring me some essence--let me sleep!
" Time flies! " say they, " You've
Little Time for work!"
Ah, but Time drags and will not
move,
She tortures me, and on her face a
smirk.
All the night through, foul Care whips
My fevered brain—What boots Love?
'Tis but a mocking mask that slips
And shows Deceit, a talon in a pretty
glove.

FOLLY.
Come with me, my pretty one,
Come and frolic, come and play
On the greensward in the sun,
Hear the birds rejoice. 'Tis day!
Let Time go, for what care we;
Here's a cordial I have made--Drink! Now you shall be free;
Dame Care stands abashed—afraid.
Why not kill old Melancholy?
They are fools who will deny
That Time is fleeting, Love is folly,
Wisdom's foolish---so am I.
"Vanitas Vos Liberabit."

EDITORIAL.
HE resignation of Mr. S. Meade Reynolds and Mr. Arthur Bloomfield
from TEE NEWS-LETTER is most unfortunate for the best interests of
the paper. Mr. Reynolds has in particular borne the burdens of THE
NEWS-LF:TTF;R, which are more considerable than is generally realized.
To him is due the increase in popularity of the periodical by the introduction of new ideas and more interesting material. It is customary
for the remaining members of THE NEWS-LETTER Board to prophecy
a brilliant future for all those who resign, but the writer feels sure that
the former editors are well able to take care of themselves anyway—in
fact, better able than the paper itself. In their case it would be more
trite than usual. So the paper only hopes (very selfishly) to get along as well as the two
former members. It extends its heartiest thanks to them and its best hopes and wishes and
all that sort of thing—if they want them.

HE NEWS-LETTER, as may be seen from the list of editors, is now in new
hands. After congratulating the former editors for their lucky escape
from the paper, it is customary to look around and see the whereabouts of
the present Board and the amount of damage to be done. It will be
the policy of the survivors to take a cheerful view of things. It has
previously been a rather usual and obvious thing to do when in want of
something better to write of to decry the lack of spirit, or the lack of
what not, and if nothing real could be found to use a great amount of
ingenuity to find a bone of contention. Not to be accused of smug selfsatisfiedness, we would at least call the attention of our readers to the
fact that whatever else may happen, the University will probably keep on its clock-like
progress, our friend Walter will cut the hair of our grandsons to his accompaniment of "yes
sirs," and what is more probable, we will continue to say "when we move to Homewood"
until some millionaire of a joking frame of mind plays a trick on the University in its sleep
and turns it out in the country to pasture. Nothing daunted by this, TILE NEWS-LETTER
will endeavor to look upon both the cheerful side of things and the serious side. It only hopes
that it will not have to say, `Apres moi le deluge."

HERE is one custom which has died out completely, but which is well
worth the trouble of resurrecting. It is Hopkins Night. For the benefit
of the Freshmen it might be well to say that heretofore one night a
week was fixed upon for Hopkins Night, and on that night the students
made themselves prominent at the show which was selected. It is the
duty of the Seniors to revive this lost custom. They should elect a
committee to take charge of the matter. This committee in turn should

TO WILLIAM BLAKE.
Painter—Poet.

All in the garden of worlds sit I,
While blossoms dropfrom the pale Moon Tree
And Starflowers wave in the Wind of Time.
And I say, "0 Dearling, come to me,
While Now is Now, and Thou art Thou
And I am 1, and We are We.
Come to me! I love you fair!
Come climb with me the Golden Stair
Until we reach the realm of Where.
Wreathes of Starlets, shalt thou wear!
We of Time shall n'er heed there,
We have nothing to beware
Let this moon bloom grace your hair.

Then comes the Garden Girl to me
And we gather the shining flowers,
And glorious wreathes we make us there
Nor reach the winging hours
While we love us each all fulsomely,
And never was love like ours.
Then from the balcony of pearl
We view the whole world swirl,
Borne onward by the swift Time whirl,
Watch the Time Wind heave and furl
Little care we how it curl,
Nor where it twirl, or fling or hurl,
The Girl loves me, I love the Girl!

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE FATE OF THE FLYING-DUTCHMAN.
V
The flying dutchman sailed the sea, a most
annoying spook
He stirred up storms and raised cain with his
trusty long shebook,
He uttered most blood-curdling shrieks, and
loved to bathe in gore,
He gnashed his teeth and laughed aloud as he
waved his sharp claymore.

The maiden all unconscious still came lightly
up the lane,
The rascal gripped his dagger hard, then
sighed as if in pain,
His muscles they refused to move, for by a
chance he'd seen
The soft and velvet colors of her eyes of grayish green.

II
Now this old ghost was hard of heart and
never was afraid,
He never had been touched or moved by any
helpless maid,
But rather yelled hooloo hoola, and grabbed
his skene' dhu,
Then pounced upon the helpless child and
slashed her thru and thru.

VI
Her pink complexion next he saw, and then
her wavy hair,
And all the poor old Dutchman did, was just
stand still and stare,
His heart beat fast and faster still, love at first
sight you know,
Alas, for all this poor man's hopes, his suit
could never go.

III
This spectre not so long ago, sailed up to
Baltimore,
And with most malicious intent he landed on
the shore,
He wandered out to Roland Park to see whom
he might kill,
When, suddenly this blackguard knave started
and stood quite still.

VII
For he was made of atmosphere, with nothing
solid there,
And so his hopes were all in vain, and he was
in despair,
But yet his heart that once was cold still beat
an awful pace,
Tiil finally it widely burst and scattered him
in space.

IV
For coming up from Maiden Lane, there tripped a little Miss,
All dressed in gray with feathers gay, just
sweet enough to kiss,
The ruffian smiled and smacked his lips, and
grunting here's my prey,
With his stiletto in his hand he stood across
her way.

VIII
The Flying-Dutchman is no more, all sailors
safely sail,
And fear no more his frightful ship, nor hear
his pealing wail,
And all this was accomplished by one fair
maiden small,
Who vanquished in a moment, what for years
made brave men pall.

IX
The Plying-Dutchman is no more, but this
bright maiden fair
Still moves along her conquering ways and
drives men to despair,
None with any chance of success, describe her
charms so fine,
But with the crowd which sings her praise, I'll
join right straight in line.
G. P.

THE DEATH OF THE PURPLE COW.

At last the Good King turned to his son
and said; "My son there is but one way to
win back the kingdom—we must first get rid
of the Purple Cow."
"The Purple Cow—who ever saw a Purple
Cow?" said Romin interrupting.
"It is the source of all our trouble, for it is
decreed by the fates that as long as the Purple Cow shall be, the country will be in the
power of the Dwarf King. And the cunning
fellow knowing this has put a spell on her so
that she may never die," said the King.
"Well, what's the use if we can't kill her?"
asked Romin.
"Stay," said the King, "tell me if the cow
should be painted would she be a purple cow,
no she would be a pink cow, a green cow, or
a plaid cow according to the chiarascuro."
"0, I know, we will buy some easter egg
dye and paint her green with pink spots and
then we will call her the Comic Supplement
Cow. And if it does not break the spell nothing will, and we will draw pictures of her and
write poems about her, and exhibit her in Mr.
Barnum's circus and in the far land, and then
is our fortune assuredly assured."
After apologizing to Mr. Gellett Burgess
for the use of his Purple Cow, we would
assure our readers that as usual the Prince
married the beautiful Princess, and every one
except the Purple Cow lived happily ever
after.
C. B.
TO MARGARET

5

TO MARGARET
(Who asks for Something Original.)

I believe you have asked me for something
new—
You must have "something original"
You don't want a sonnet to "eyes of blue,"
You don't want a ballad of "Love that's true,"
Such things appeal to the "masses," butyou
You must have "something original."
II
Well, then, Miss Margaret, of what shall I
write,
Since you must have "something original,"
I cannot write of your brown eyes, bright,
I cannot write of your hands, so white,
Nor yet of your foot-steps, airy and light,
For that would not be original.
III
You ask, you request, you almost implore
For something wholly original,
That stops me from saying how much "I
adore,"
From saying "I love you"—and saying much
more,
That I fear I have said too often before—
Because it would not be original.
IV
I've written already of ladies' "brown hair,"
So that would not be original!
I've told others before that they were "most
fair;''
So, however I strive and however I dare—
Though I give all my time, and my thoughts
and my care—
I can't write "something original."

(Who asks for Something Original.)

If Breakfast Foods were good to eat,
And Packingtown sold really meat,
And sugared sand were truly sweet,
Why then I'd be original.
If some day I should drink some paint,
And see things really as they ain't,
I might in time become a saint,
Which would be quite original.
If you suggest it why then I'll
Do it. But is it worth while
Just to get a tiny smile,
To be original?
No! Rather would I live and die
Commonplacely eating pie
Than in such a way that I
Should be original.

V
I can keep up these verses forever, you know,
(Though of course they are not original.)
For whether the lines move swiftly, or slow,
Softly or loudly, high or low,
It's always the same—they continue to go;
But never, ah never, original!
VI
Perhaps, sometime, on a far-off day,
I may write "something original."
I don't say I shall, but simply "I may,"
(I use great care in whatever I say)
And then, if you happen to happen my way,
I'll send you "something original!"
—S. C. C.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

COLLEGE TEAM FOR HOPKINS.
To the Editor of the News-Letter.
DEAR

SIR-

The keynote has been sounded, the chord
struck ! Now let the halls of our Alma Mater
resound with the slogan—"An undergraduate
football team." A college team is necessarily
an instigator of spirit, but the 'varsity football team for which men strive with the single
desire to raise their college in athletic fame is
without doubt the foundation of the real,
college spirit. Hopkins wants a team composed of men with whom we associate daily,
whom we know and love as college chums,
and whose efforts we can appreciate and encourage, and not a team of men, perhaps
famous on the football field, but whom we
know merely by name. Hopkins needs a team
for which men come out in order to better it
and not just for their own exercise. Hopkins
must have a team every member of which, in
the hour of defeat, fight with the dogged
determination that their college banner will
not trail in the dust, and not from a mere
personal objection to being the under dog.
For such a team there are several essentials,
but first of all undergraduate members. Then
we must have an experienced coach. A coach
who could turn a winning team out of the
unlearned, but willing material offered. Hopkins could not expect from the existing classes
a heavy team, say an average of a hundred
and fifty. But if the green country gawks of
villages like Thurmont, many of whom had
never before seen a football, could be thrashed
into the existing Western Maryland Team,
a winning one though light, Hopkins would
beat St. John's next year.
The elimination of. the training-table expenses at Tierney's would more than enable
Hopkins to afford a professional coach, if the
phrase may be employed, a man whose profession is football coaching. The steps has
already been taken to have an undergraduate
captain. A capable, experienced player an

influential man at Hopkins, but above all a
"hustler" is desired. At present four undergraduates are on the football team. If an
undergraduate team is to be started for next
year will it be fair to that embryo team for the
existing team to choose the captain? Why
not have the athletic board appoint a captain
pro tern., who will push things along till next
year's team has gotten together, and then let
that team or body of men choose their own
captain. Next year we will most likely have
a field to practice on at Homewood, a great
advantage over this year's team. Let us all
hope for a better team! But let us show our
hopes by getting together and working.
Upon the ruins, let everybody take a hand and
build an invincible Rome, with no fear that
Carthage in the shape of St. John's may be
lurking around the corner.
EvP.',LETH H. BRIDGMAN.

KING LUDWIG'S CASTLE.
Now am I poet of poets,
No dream castles flimsy build I
For I shape the dross into poems
My castle soars into the sky
High on the mountain I built thee,
High, ever higher, most high.
0 ye ten thousand candles
Yield up your lives till ye die!
Start! shine! flame! into brightness
Light ye! Let fire flowers fly!
Myriads of crystals! 0 glitter!
Strain ye the swift flaming lights
Burst! Burst yourselves blazing!
Dazzle thy lord monarch's sight!
For my dear lady love of a palace
With star gems must well be bedight
They say I am mad—let them think it,
My marrows all surge with delight
And if 1 am king in the day time
Thrice thrice am I king in the night.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

SONNET.
"And then the Love,
sighing like a furnace, with a woful ballad
made to his Mistress eye-brow."—As You Like If.

Dan Cupid once, upon a bed of roses
Fell fast asleep—it was a summer's day.
My lady-love was coming by that way;
Her fate a moment opportune discloses.
Softly she stole up to the god, asleep;
A quiver full of love darts by his side,
And on his back two fairy bows she spied,
For two bows Cupid always has to keep
Lest one be broken. She took bows and darts;
The latter in her eyes she put straightway,
And with them her endeavor is to slay
Mine and all other longing, loving hearts.
And the two bows she places o'er her eyes,
To be protectors of so dear a prize.—S. C. C.

SONNET: TO A ROSE.
Thou dost not give thy fragrance to the air
For many days, and thy soft petals frail,
Purer than star-light, than the dawn more pale,
Are not for many hours pure and fair.
The winds of Araby cannot compare
To one breath of thy beauty, flower divine
Fresher they perfume than the forest pine,
Softer thy bloom than sylvan maiden hair.
And though thy beauty lasteth but a night
It giveth pleasure without future cloy,
And is for aye a 'lasting mine of joy,"
A constant source of pleasure and delight.
But oh! thou fadest, and then, alas, so fleet
Thy fall is that it leaves but memory sweet!
S. C. C.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

ST. JOHN'S, 2—HOPKINS, 0.
The same old Hoodoo. St. John's won 2
to Q. To be sure there was some dispute
about the score, and many claim, with pretty
good grounds, that there should be no two
points and that what was called a safety was
really a plain everyday touchback. We will
not make any statements concerning the decision for the referee decided it was a safety,
and the fact remains that Johns Hopkins did
not win although they should have.
Same old story, lack of practice, especially
in catching punts, and lack of condition. The
catching of punts on such a day required a
master hand, for behind each punt there
rushed a 40-mile-an-hour wind which upset
all ordinary conditions and changed matters
greatly.
The game began with Hopkins against the
wind. The Black and Blue started with a
rush and plowed thru St. John's line at will,
only to lose the ball on a fumble in the middle
of the field. St. John's immediately kicked
and with the wind behind it the ball landed
far behind Hopkins goal line for a touchback.
This course of procedure was kept up all during the first half until finally the ball struck
Chesney's ahoulder and bounded back of the
goal line. Chesney touched the ball down
without attempting to advance it, but the
referee declared it a safety and the only score
of the game resulted.
In the second half Hopkins kicked off with
the wind. Here it seemed that there was
some lack of headwork shown, for, instead of
taking advantage of the strong wind and
punting more the Hopkinsites rushed the ball
almost continually. Towards the middle of
the second half Hopkins was going down the
field at will, but after a beautiful 30-yard run,
Hart dropped the ball as he was tackled on
St. John's 15-yard line, and a seemingly sure
touchdown was nipped in the bud. Toward
the end of the second half the better condition
of the St. Johns team enabled them to withstand Hopkins rushes and when the whistle
blew both teams were just about able to hold
each other off without any appreciable gain
for either side.
There were some noteworthy points of interest, and one of these was the work of
Michael. Babe played in better form than he

has for some time, and on his tackle thru
tackle play made several good gains. The
back field worked together in fine shape and
Hart and Webb tore off some good end runs.
Hopkins line men charged well and managed
to get thru and effectively break up several
attempted place kicks. Last, but not least,
the work of Ridgely deserves praise. To our
way of thinking the work of Ridgely has been
worthy of mention all during the year. At
end, Ridgely plays hard, uses his head well,
and fights every minute of the time with a
spirit that is good to look upon. It is just
that hard fighting spirit which doesent take
into account personal inconvenience that is
needed at Hopkins, and it is a pity that more
of the undergraduates and graduate members
have not seen fit to show it. The spirit is
needed, not only on the football team, but in
every other branch of college activities, and
it is conspicuous for its absence among the
few rooters at the games.
There was much improvement shown by
the students at the St. John's game, for quite
a large number of rooters accompanied the
team and did their best. But there were not
enough and every man who was not there
should be ashamed of himself.

HOPKINS, 6—UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND, 0.
The season ended on Thanksgiving Day
with a victory for us over our old rivals, the
red and black warriors of the University of
Maryland, by the score of 6 to 0. Our
opponents were rather confident of victory,
after the defeat of Hopkins, the week before,
at the hands of St. John's, and were disagreeably surprised at the outcome of the
game. This makes the third successive defeat
which J. H. U. has administered to the
University of Maryland.
There was a good large crowd present, in
spite of the fact that the M. A. C.,—Catonsville game attracted many people. University
of Maryland had a bunch of rooters, much
larger than that which wore the black and
blue, and Maryland's colors were decidedly
more in evidence than those of Hopkins.
Maryland was so discourteous as to hiss the
Hopkins' team when they came out on the

THE NEWS-LETTER.

field—an act which is not likely to produce
good feeling between the two Universities.
The game was well-played throughout,
both teams fighting hard, but it cannot be
denied that Hopkins showed the better form,
both in kicking, and in advancing the ball.
Michael punted better than at any time this
year, and, in addition, made several good end
runs on fake-kicks. Not one Hopkins punt
was blocked, while several attempted drop
kicks by Maryland were blocked everytime.
Rarely did Maryland gain first down, and
were forced to kick often.
The touch-down came in the second half.
Michael kicked a long punt which the quarterback missed, and Ridgely recovered on Marylands 25 yard line.
An end run was
attempted, and then a forward pass gained
about fifteen yards. From this point, Stewart,
by two line bucks, placed the ball on Maryland's four-yard line, whence Michael took it
over for the final score, Moss kicking goal.
The work of our ends was particularly good,
both on defensive and on running down under
kicks. Ridgely was hurt in the second half
and forced to retire, giving away to Brotherhood. Michael carried the ball well through
tackle, making several substantial gains. The
back-field played well together, and the line
held finely.
The victory was more or less unexpected,
and was all the more welcome. It was a
fitting ending for a more or less unsuccessful
season. What the team needs next year, is a
scrub. This year, there has been no scrub
eleven to line up against, and all the team
could do was to practice signals. Next year,
let us hope to see a large bunch of enthusiastic,
candidates come out and form a strong second
eleven to give 'Varsity a rub. We must make
good next year.
A. M. C.

CLASS FOOTBALL.
- Who is going to win the class game? The
only way to tell that is to toss up a coin.
The teams are evenly matched, and the game
should certainly be an exciting one. Glancing at the personnel of the two teams, we find
good meterial on both sides. On the Junior
line we find Tilghman, Hecht, Mathias, Williams, Wegefarth, Ridgely, Armstrong, Bren-

9

ton, Frank and Breyer. This line will average less than the Freshman line, because
Michael will help to increase 1909's weight.
In the Junior back-field are Abel, Streett,
Bridgeman, Thompson and Chesney. From
the above squad will be picked the team which
will represent 1908. At present it seems
probable that Ridgely may not be able to get
in the game owing to injuries in the Thanksgiving game.
Opposed to them will be a heavier team.
On the Freshman line will be Michael, Donnell and Warren Stewart, Sattler, Maynard,
Bonebrake, Russell, Maddren and Bevan.
This constitutes a heavy and strong line. In
the Freshman back-field are Chandlee, Bailey,
Bird, Gutman, all of whom are fast, and have
had some experience. With this array 1909
ought to put up a creditable game.
The class games are always interesting, and
attract a large crowd. This year's game
should be doubly attractive, owing to the fact
that the teams are so evenly matched. Following the class game will come the cane-rush.
Last year the class of 1908 lost, but they will
do their utmost to win this year. Let us hope
the best team will win.

THE NEWS-LETTER will offer 2 prizes for
the best 10 verses written by one person
using one of the following lines somewhere in
the verses. The first prize will be of 3 dollars,
the second of 2 dollars. The prize is withheld if 1 or more persons do not avail themselves of the opportunity. The judges of the
contest will be the Editor of THE NEWSLETTER and Mr. Walter Fernandis, who has
kindly consented to consent to any opinion
the Editor arrives at.

I wish that I were not so good.
A maiden in Ota-hu-hu.
A divinity student named Dod.
Darling Dollie, mama's pride.
My head is 3 sizes too small.
Henry had a paper eye.
A lady who lived in a quarry.
When Arabella bent her ear.
A wily young widow, named Weed.
I seldom drink ink with my meals.
Said Elmer Peavey Blinkinsop.
Poor Fido ate my diamond ring.
The town that Rudolph painted red.
The fly-paper sheets on my bed.
Little packs of playing cards.
A wistful, weary wing wale once.
When Riley rolled into the reel.
The willie boy that Bertha bought.
When Mortimer stepped off the roof.
A camel whose complexion was pink.
"Now to business," said Sue.
Little Billy stole a ride.
Pierrot spied a girl named Schlitz.
My nose was caught by a ferret.
There was a young boy from St. John's.
A clock once married a spoon.
Little Mary lost her rest.
Jim" resides in the cage so fair.
Walter stole the elevator.
Dr. Green once gave a party.
I do not use glue on my hair.
An undulating unicorn.
Evangeline, the sweet young thing.
Someone ate a periwinkle.

THE FIRST HOPKINS DANCE.
The first of the Hopkins dances is over.
There remains little to be done except to congratulate every one who was there, especially
the Board of Governors of the Johns Hopkins
Cotillon Club. A large crowd was present—
many of this season's debutantes, who seemed
to forget for the moment all cares of society
and have a thoroughly good time. The music
was exceptionally good, both in the performance and selections, which were made by Mr.
Richard MacSherry of the committee. The
floor was well polished. And this is the requirement of a good dance, beside the personal
element, that the floor and music shall be the
best. The supper was as usual, with a big
crowd fighting good naturedly for the food,
all'of which is part of the sport. Practically
every one of importance, the people that you
know, were there.
Altogether it was, as someone said, the best
Hopkins dance for years. It was better than
those of last year, which, as every one knows,
were superlatively good.

So we finally get to college,
Just a liitle after nine,
With the sweat of strength expended,
But do you hear us whine?

THE 9 O'CLOCK.
We grab a little biscuit,
We chew a hunk of meat,
We gulp a cup of coffee,
I do not say, we eat.

But the look the 'Prof." then gives you
Is a corking sight to see,
So that a class at nine is called
The course in repartee.

We run a nice four-forty
To catch the fleeting car,
Alas the thing has looped the loop,
And well then there you are!

Ilattitas Itios Kihrrabit.
EVERY MAN.
RING me some balm, oh
soothing Folly!
My Lady Care hath
scourged me deep
With all the whips of
Melancholy.
Bring me some essence--let me sleep!
" Time flies! " say they, " You've
Little Time for work!"
Ah, but Time drags and will not
move,
She tortures me, and on her face a
smirk.
All the night through, foul Care whips
My fevered brain—What boots Love?
'Tis but a mocking mask that slips
And shows Deceit, a talon in a pretty
glove.

FOLLY.
Come with me, my pretty one,
Come and frolic, come and play
On the greensward in the sun,
Hear the birds rejoice. 'Tis day!
Let Time go, for what care we;
Here's a cordial I have made--Drink! Now you shall be free;
Dame Care stands abashed—afraid.
Why not kill old Melancholy?
They are fools who will deny
That Time is fleeting, Love is folly,
Wisdom's foolish---so am I.
"Vanitas Vos Liberabit."

EDITORIAL.
HE resignation of Mr. S. Meade Reynolds and Mr. Arthur Bloomfield
from TEE NEWS-LETTER is most unfortunate for the best interests of
the paper. Mr. Reynolds has in particular borne the burdens of THE
NEWS-LF:TTF;R, which are more considerable than is generally realized.
To him is due the increase in popularity of the periodical by the introduction of new ideas and more interesting material. It is customary
for the remaining members of THE NEWS-LETTER Board to prophecy
a brilliant future for all those who resign, but the writer feels sure that
the former editors are well able to take care of themselves anyway—in
fact, better able than the paper itself. In their case it would be more
trite than usual. So the paper only hopes (very selfishly) to get along as well as the two
former members. It extends its heartiest thanks to them and its best hopes and wishes and
all that sort of thing—if they want them.

HE NEWS-LETTER, as may be seen from the list of editors, is now in new
hands. After congratulating the former editors for their lucky escape
from the paper, it is customary to look around and see the whereabouts of
the present Board and the amount of damage to be done. It will be
the policy of the survivors to take a cheerful view of things. It has
previously been a rather usual and obvious thing to do when in want of
something better to write of to decry the lack of spirit, or the lack of
what not, and if nothing real could be found to use a great amount of
ingenuity to find a bone of contention. Not to be accused of smug selfsatisfiedness, we would at least call the attention of our readers to the
fact that whatever else may happen, the University will probably keep on its clock-like
progress, our friend Walter will cut the hair of our grandsons to his accompaniment of "yes
sirs," and what is more probable, we will continue to say "when we move to Homewood"
until some millionaire of a joking frame of mind plays a trick on the University in its sleep
and turns it out in the country to pasture. Nothing daunted by this, TILE NEWS-LETTER
will endeavor to look upon both the cheerful side of things and the serious side. It only hopes
that it will not have to say, `Apres moi le deluge."

worth the trouble of resurrecting. It is Hopkins Night. For the benefit
of the Freshmen it might be well to say that heretofore one night a

TO WILLIAM BLAKE.
Painter—Poet.

All in the garden of worlds sit I,
While blossoms dropfrom the pale Moon Tree
And Starflowers wave in the Wind of Time.
And I say, "0 Dearling, come to me,
While Now is Now, and Thou art Thou
And I am 1, and We are We.
Come to me! I love you fair!
Come climb with me the Golden Stair
Until we reach the realm of Where.
Wreathes of Starlets, shalt thou wear!
We of Time shall n'er heed there,
We have nothing to beware
Let this moon bloom grace your hair.

Then comes the Garden Girl to me
And we gather the shining flowers,
And glorious wreathes we make us there
Nor reach the winging hours
While we love us each all fulsomely,
And never was love like ours.
Then from the balcony of pearl
We view the whole world swirl,
Borne onward by the swift Time whirl,
Watch the Time Wind heave and furl
Little care we how it curl,
Nor where it twirl, or fling or hurl,
The Girl loves me, I love the Girl!

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE FATE OF THE FLYING-DUTCHMAN.
V
The flying dutchman sailed the sea, a most
annoying spook
He stirred up storms and raised cain with his
trusty long shebook,
He uttered most blood-curdling shrieks, and
loved to bathe in gore,
He gnashed his teeth and laughed aloud as he
waved his sharp claymore.

The maiden all unconscious still came lightly
up the lane,
The rascal gripped his dagger hard, then
sighed as if in pain,
His muscles they refused to move, for by a
chance he'd seen
The soft and velvet colors of her eyes of grayish green.

II
Now this old ghost was hard of heart and
never was afraid,
He never had been touched or moved by any
helpless maid,
But rather yelled hooloo hoola, and grabbed
his skene' dhu,
Then pounced upon the helpless child and
slashed her thru and thru.

VI
Her pink complexion next he saw, and then
her wavy hair,
And all the poor old Dutchman did, was just
stand still and stare,
His heart beat fast and faster still, love at first
sight you know,
Alas, for all this poor man's hopes, his suit
could never go.

III
This spectre not so long ago, sailed up to
Baltimore,
And with most malicious intent he landed on
the shore,
He wandered out to Roland Park to see whom
he might kill,
When, suddenly this blackguard knave started
and stood quite still.

VII
For he was made of atmosphere, with nothing
solid there,
And so his hopes were all in vain, and he was
in despair,
But yet his heart that once was cold still beat
an awful pace,
Tiil finally it widely burst and scattered him
in space.

IV
For coming up from Maiden Lane, there tripped a little Miss,
All dressed in gray with feathers gay, just
sweet enough to kiss,
The ruffian smiled and smacked his lips, and
grunting here's my prey,
With his stiletto in his hand he stood across
her way.

VIII
The Flying-Dutchman is no more, all sailors
safely sail,
And fear no more his frightful ship, nor hear
his pealing wail,
And all this was accomplished by one fair
maiden small,
Who vanquished in a moment, what for years
made brave men pall.

IX
The Plying-Dutchman is no more, but this
bright maiden fair
Still moves along her conquering ways and
drives men to despair,
None with any chance of success, describe her
charms so fine,
But with the crowd which sings her praise, I'll
join right straight in line.
G. P.

At last the Good King turned to his son
and said; "My son there is but one way to
win back the kingdom—we must first get rid
of the Purple Cow."
"The Purple Cow—who ever saw a Purple
Cow?" said Romin interrupting.
"It is the source of all our trouble, for it is
decreed by the fates that as long as the Purple Cow shall be, the country will be in the
power of the Dwarf King. And the cunning
fellow knowing this has put a spell on her so
that she may never die," said the King.
"Well, what's the use if we can't kill her?"
asked Romin.
"Stay," said the King, "tell me if the cow
should be painted would she be a purple cow,
no she would be a pink cow, a green cow, or
a plaid cow according to the chiarascuro."
"0, I know, we will buy some easter egg
dye and paint her green with pink spots and
then we will call her the Comic Supplement
Cow. And if it does not break the spell nothing will, and we will draw pictures of her and
write poems about her, and exhibit her in Mr.
Barnum's circus and in the far land, and then
is our fortune assuredly assured."
After apologizing to Mr. Gellett Burgess
for the use of his Purple Cow, we would
assure our readers that as usual the Prince
married the beautiful Princess, and every one
except the Purple Cow lived happily ever
after.
C. B.
TO MARGARET

5

TO MARGARET
(Who asks for Something Original.)

I believe you have asked me for something
new—
You must have "something original"
You don't want a sonnet to "eyes of blue,"
You don't want a ballad of "Love that's true,"
Such things appeal to the "masses," butyou
You must have "something original."
II
Well, then, Miss Margaret, of what shall I
write,
Since you must have "something original,"
I cannot write of your brown eyes, bright,
I cannot write of your hands, so white,
Nor yet of your foot-steps, airy and light,
For that would not be original.
III
You ask, you request, you almost implore
For something wholly original,
That stops me from saying how much "I
adore,"
From saying "I love you"—and saying much
more,
That I fear I have said too often before—
Because it would not be original.
IV
I've written already of ladies' "brown hair,"
So that would not be original!
I've told others before that they were "most
fair;''
So, however I strive and however I dare—
Though I give all my time, and my thoughts
and my care—
I can't write "something original."

(Who asks for Something Original.)

If Breakfast Foods were good to eat,
And Packingtown sold really meat,
And sugared sand were truly sweet,
Why then I'd be original.
If some day I should drink some paint,
And see things really as they ain't,
I might in time become a saint,
Which would be quite original.
If you suggest it why then I'll
Do it. But is it worth while
Just to get a tiny smile,
To be original?
No! Rather would I live and die
Commonplacely eating pie
Than in such a way that I
Should be original.

V
I can keep up these verses forever, you know,
(Though of course they are not original.)
For whether the lines move swiftly, or slow,
Softly or loudly, high or low,
It's always the same—they continue to go;
But never, ah never, original!
VI
Perhaps, sometime, on a far-off day,
I may write "something original."
I don't say I shall, but simply "I may,"
(I use great care in whatever I say)
And then, if you happen to happen my way,
I'll send you "something original!"
—S. C. C.

COLLEGE TEAM FOR HOPKINS.
To the Editor of the News-Letter.
DEAR

SIR-

The keynote has been sounded, the chord
struck ! Now let the halls of our Alma Mater
resound with the slogan—"An undergraduate
football team." A college team is necessarily
an instigator of spirit, but the 'varsity football team for which men strive with the single
desire to raise their college in athletic fame is
without doubt the foundation of the real,
college spirit. Hopkins wants a team composed of men with whom we associate daily,
whom we know and love as college chums,
and whose efforts we can appreciate and encourage, and not a team of men, perhaps
famous on the football field, but whom we
know merely by name. Hopkins needs a team
for which men come out in order to better it
and not just for their own exercise. Hopkins
must have a team every member of which, in
the hour of defeat, fight with the dogged
determination that their college banner will
not trail in the dust, and not from a mere
personal objection to being the under dog.
For such a team there are several essentials,
but first of all undergraduate members. Then
we must have an experienced coach. A coach
who could turn a winning team out of the
unlearned, but willing material offered. Hopkins could not expect from the existing classes
a heavy team, say an average of a hundred
and fifty. But if the green country gawks of
villages like Thurmont, many of whom had
never before seen a football, could be thrashed
into the existing Western Maryland Team,
a winning one though light, Hopkins would
beat St. John's next year.
The elimination of. the training-table expenses at Tierney's would more than enable
Hopkins to afford a professional coach, if the
phrase may be employed, a man whose profession is football coaching. The steps has
already been taken to have an undergraduate
captain. A capable, experienced player an

influential man at Hopkins, but above all a
"hustler" is desired. At present four undergraduates are on the football team. If an
undergraduate team is to be started for next
year will it be fair to that embryo team for the
existing team to choose the captain? Why
not have the athletic board appoint a captain
pro tern., who will push things along till next
year's team has gotten together, and then let
that team or body of men choose their own
captain. Next year we will most likely have
a field to practice on at Homewood, a great
advantage over this year's team. Let us all
hope for a better team! But let us show our
hopes by getting together and working.
Upon the ruins, let everybody take a hand and
build an invincible Rome, with no fear that
Carthage in the shape of St. John's may be
lurking around the corner.
EvP.',LETH H. BRIDGMAN.

KING LUDWIG'S CASTLE.
Now am I poet of poets,
No dream castles flimsy build I
For I shape the dross into poems
My castle soars into the sky
High on the mountain I built thee,
High, ever higher, most high.
0 ye ten thousand candles
Yield up your lives till ye die!
Start! shine! flame! into brightness
Light ye! Let fire flowers fly!
Myriads of crystals! 0 glitter!
Strain ye the swift flaming lights
Burst! Burst yourselves blazing!
Dazzle thy lord monarch's sight!
For my dear lady love of a palace
With star gems must well be bedight
They say I am mad—let them think it,
My marrows all surge with delight
And if 1 am king in the day time
Thrice thrice am I king in the night.

SONNET.
"And then the Love,
sighing like a furnace, with a woful ballad
made to his Mistress eye-brow."—As You Like If.

Dan Cupid once, upon a bed of roses
Fell fast asleep—it was a summer's day.
My lady-love was coming by that way;
Her fate a moment opportune discloses.
Softly she stole up to the god, asleep;
A quiver full of love darts by his side,
And on his back two fairy bows she spied,
For two bows Cupid always has to keep
Lest one be broken. She took bows and darts;
The latter in her eyes she put straightway,
And with them her endeavor is to slay
Mine and all other longing, loving hearts.
And the two bows she places o'er her eyes,
To be protectors of so dear a prize.—S. C. C.

SONNET: TO A ROSE.
Thou dost not give thy fragrance to the air
For many days, and thy soft petals frail,
Purer than star-light, than the dawn more pale,
Are not for many hours pure and fair.
The winds of Araby cannot compare
To one breath of thy beauty, flower divine
Fresher they perfume than the forest pine,
Softer thy bloom than sylvan maiden hair.
And though thy beauty lasteth but a night
It giveth pleasure without future cloy,
And is for aye a 'lasting mine of joy,"
A constant source of pleasure and delight.
But oh! thou fadest, and then, alas, so fleet
Thy fall is that it leaves but memory sweet!
S. C. C.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

ST. JOHN'S, 2—HOPKINS, 0.
The same old Hoodoo. St. John's won 2
to Q. To be sure there was some dispute
about the score, and many claim, with pretty
good grounds, that there should be no two
points and that what was called a safety was
really a plain everyday touchback. We will
not make any statements concerning the decision for the referee decided it was a safety,
and the fact remains that Johns Hopkins did
not win although they should have.
Same old story, lack of practice, especially
in catching punts, and lack of condition. The
catching of punts on such a day required a
master hand, for behind each punt there
rushed a 40-mile-an-hour wind which upset
all ordinary conditions and changed matters
greatly.
The game began with Hopkins against the
wind. The Black and Blue started with a
rush and plowed thru St. John's line at will,
only to lose the ball on a fumble in the middle
of the field. St. John's immediately kicked
and with the wind behind it the ball landed
far behind Hopkins goal line for a touchback.
This course of procedure was kept up all during the first half until finally the ball struck
Chesney's ahoulder and bounded back of the
goal line. Chesney touched the ball down
without attempting to advance it, but the
referee declared it a safety and the only score
of the game resulted.
In the second half Hopkins kicked off with
the wind. Here it seemed that there was
some lack of headwork shown, for, instead of
taking advantage of the strong wind and
punting more the Hopkinsites rushed the ball
almost continually. Towards the middle of
the second half Hopkins was going down the
field at will, but after a beautiful 30-yard run,
Hart dropped the ball as he was tackled on
St. John's 15-yard line, and a seemingly sure
touchdown was nipped in the bud. Toward
the end of the second half the better condition
of the St. Johns team enabled them to withstand Hopkins rushes and when the whistle
blew both teams were just about able to hold
each other off without any appreciable gain
for either side.
There were some noteworthy points of interest, and one of these was the work of
Michael. Babe played in better form than he

has for some time, and on his tackle thru
tackle play made several good gains. The
back field worked together in fine shape and
Hart and Webb tore off some good end runs.
Hopkins line men charged well and managed
to get thru and effectively break up several
attempted place kicks. Last, but not least,
the work of Ridgely deserves praise. To our
way of thinking the work of Ridgely has been
worthy of mention all during the year. At
end, Ridgely plays hard, uses his head well,
and fights every minute of the time with a
spirit that is good to look upon. It is just
that hard fighting spirit which doesent take
into account personal inconvenience that is
needed at Hopkins, and it is a pity that more
of the undergraduates and graduate members
have not seen fit to show it. The spirit is
needed, not only on the football team, but in
every other branch of college activities, and
it is conspicuous for its absence among the
few rooters at the games.
There was much improvement shown by
the students at the St. John's game, for quite
a large number of rooters accompanied the
team and did their best. But there were not
enough and every man who was not there
should be ashamed of himself.

HOPKINS, 6—UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND, 0.
The season ended on Thanksgiving Day
with a victory for us over our old rivals, the
red and black warriors of the University of
Maryland, by the score of 6 to 0. Our
opponents were rather confident of victory,
after the defeat of Hopkins, the week before,
at the hands of St. John's, and were disagreeably surprised at the outcome of the
game. This makes the third successive defeat
which J. H. U. has administered to the
University of Maryland.
There was a good large crowd present, in
spite of the fact that the M. A. C.,—Catonsville game attracted many people. University
of Maryland had a bunch of rooters, much
larger than that which wore the black and
blue, and Maryland's colors were decidedly
more in evidence than those of Hopkins.
Maryland was so discourteous as to hiss the
Hopkins' team when they came out on the

THE NEWS-LETTER.

field—an act which is not likely to produce
good feeling between the two Universities.
The game was well-played throughout,
both teams fighting hard, but it cannot be
denied that Hopkins showed the better form,
both in kicking, and in advancing the ball.
Michael punted better than at any time this
year, and, in addition, made several good end
runs on fake-kicks. Not one Hopkins punt
was blocked, while several attempted drop
kicks by Maryland were blocked everytime.
Rarely did Maryland gain first down, and
were forced to kick often.
The touch-down came in the second half.
Michael kicked a long punt which the quarterback missed, and Ridgely recovered on Marylands 25 yard line.
An end run was
attempted, and then a forward pass gained
about fifteen yards. From this point, Stewart,
by two line bucks, placed the ball on Maryland's four-yard line, whence Michael took it
over for the final score, Moss kicking goal.
The work of our ends was particularly good,
both on defensive and on running down under
kicks. Ridgely was hurt in the second half
and forced to retire, giving away to Brotherhood. Michael carried the ball well through
tackle, making several substantial gains. The
back-field played well together, and the line
held finely.
The victory was more or less unexpected,
and was all the more welcome. It was a
fitting ending for a more or less unsuccessful
season. What the team needs next year, is a
scrub. This year, there has been no scrub
eleven to line up against, and all the team
could do was to practice signals. Next year,
let us hope to see a large bunch of enthusiastic,
candidates come out and form a strong second
eleven to give 'Varsity a rub. We must make
good next year.
A. M. C.

CLASS FOOTBALL.
- Who is going to win the class game? The
only way to tell that is to toss up a coin.
The teams are evenly matched, and the game
should certainly be an exciting one. Glancing at the personnel of the two teams, we find
good meterial on both sides. On the Junior
line we find Tilghman, Hecht, Mathias, Williams, Wegefarth, Ridgely, Armstrong, Bren-

9

ton, Frank and Breyer. This line will average less than the Freshman line, because
Michael will help to increase 1909's weight.
In the Junior back-field are Abel, Streett,
Bridgeman, Thompson and Chesney. From
the above squad will be picked the team which
will represent 1908. At present it seems
probable that Ridgely may not be able to get
in the game owing to injuries in the Thanksgiving game.
Opposed to them will be a heavier team.
On the Freshman line will be Michael, Donnell and Warren Stewart, Sattler, Maynard,
Bonebrake, Russell, Maddren and Bevan.
This constitutes a heavy and strong line. In
the Freshman back-field are Chandlee, Bailey,
Bird, Gutman, all of whom are fast, and have
had some experience. With this array 1909
ought to put up a creditable game.
The class games are always interesting, and
attract a large crowd. This year's game
should be doubly attractive, owing to the fact
that the teams are so evenly matched. Following the class game will come the cane-rush.
Last year the class of 1908 lost, but they will
do their utmost to win this year. Let us hope
the best team will win.

THE NEWS-LETTER CONTEST.
THE NEWS-LETTER will offer 2 prizes for
the best 10 verses written by one person
using one of the following lines somewhere in
the verses. The first prize will be of 3 dollars,
the second of 2 dollars. The prize is withheld if 1 or more persons do not avail themselves of the opportunity. The judges of the
contest will be the Editor of THE NEWSLETTER and Mr. Walter Fernandis, who has
kindly consented to consent to any opinion
the Editor arrives at.

I wish that I were not so good.
A maiden in Ota-hu-hu.
A divinity student named Dod.
Darling Dollie, mama's pride.
My head is 3 sizes too small.
Henry had a paper eye.
A lady who lived in a quarry.
When Arabella bent her ear.
A wily young widow, named Weed.
I seldom drink ink with my meals.
Said Elmer Peavey Blinkinsop.
Poor Fido ate my diamond ring.
The town that Rudolph painted red.
The fly-paper sheets on my bed.
Little packs of playing cards.
A wistful, weary wing wale once.
When Riley rolled into the reel.
The willie boy that Bertha bought.
When Mortimer stepped off the roof.
A camel whose complexion was pink.
"Now to business," said Sue.
Little Billy stole a ride.
Pierrot spied a girl named Schlitz.
My nose was caught by a ferret.
There was a young boy from St. John's.
A clock once married a spoon.
Little Mary lost her rest.
Jim" resides in the cage so fair.
Walter stole the elevator.
Dr. Green once gave a party.
I do not use glue on my hair.
An undulating unicorn.
Evangeline, the sweet young thing.
Someone ate a periwinkle.

THE FIRST HOPKINS DANCE.
The first of the Hopkins dances is over.
There remains little to be done except to congratulate every one who was there, especially
the Board of Governors of the Johns Hopkins
Cotillon Club. A large crowd was present—
many of this season's debutantes, who seemed
to forget for the moment all cares of society
and have a thoroughly good time. The music
was exceptionally good, both in the performance and selections, which were made by Mr.
Richard MacSherry of the committee. The
floor was well polished. And this is the requirement of a good dance, beside the personal
element, that the floor and music shall be the
best. The supper was as usual, with a big
crowd fighting good naturedly for the food,
all'of which is part of the sport. Practically
every one of importance, the people that you
know, were there.
Altogether it was, as someone said, the best
Hopkins dance for years. It was better than
those of last year, which, as every one knows,
were superlatively good.

So we finally get to college,
Just a liitle after nine,
With the sweat of strength expended,
But do you hear us whine?

THE 9 O'CLOCK.
We grab a little biscuit,
We chew a hunk of meat,
We gulp a cup of coffee,
I do not say, we eat.

But the look the 'Prof." then gives you
Is a corking sight to see,
So that a class at nine is called
The course in repartee.

We run a nice four-forty
To catch the fleeting car,
Alas the thing has looped the loop,
And well then there you are!
